facts.text: The Beedi and Cigar Workers (Conditions of Employment) Act, 1966 is challenged as unconstitutional in petitions and appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Beedi and Cigar Workers  Condition of Employment  Act, 1966 referred to as the Act are impeached as unconstitutional in these petitions and appeals.

facts.text: Petitioners and appellants are proprietors of beedi factories, owners of trademarks registered under Trade Marks Act, and some home workers.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners and the appellants are of two characters. The majority are proprietors of beedi factories and owners trade mark registered under the Trade Marks Act in relation to beedis. Some are home workers.

facts.text: Beedi manufacture involves blending tobacco, putting on beedi leaf, rolling, closing ends, collecting, warming/roasting, packing, labelling.

anchor.surface_text: The beedi industry is widespread in this Country, The manufacture of beedi is done in stages. The tobacco is blended often with some other ingredient. A small quantity of it is put on the beedi leaf which is previously wet to render it flexible to prevent any crushing of leaf and is also cut to size. The beedi leaf is then rolled keeping the tobacco within it and its ends are then closed.

facts.text: Three systems in beedi manufacture: factory system, contract system (most prevalent), outworkers/home workers.

anchor.surface_text: Three systems arc adopted in the manufacture of beedis. First, is the factory system. There the manufacture is an owner of the factory. Workers gather and work under his supervision as his employees. Second is the companytract system of employment. That is the most prevalent form.

facts.text: Contractors engage labourers less than statutory number to evade Factories Act; fragmentation to avoid factory legislation.

anchor.surface_text: Under these systems, the companytractor engages labourers less than the statutory number to escape the application of the Factories Act. There is a fragmentation of the place of manufacture of beedis with a view to evading the factory legislation.

facts.text: Royal Commission on Labour in India (1931) found beedi industry widespread, poor conditions in small workshops.

anchor.surface_text: There was a Royal Commission on Labour in India in 1931. The findings were these. The making of beedi is an industry widely spread over the companyntry. It is partly carried on in the home but mainly in the workshops in the bigger cities and towns.

facts.text: Rege Committee (1944) investigated industrial labour conditions, noted contract system issues in beedi industry.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944, the Government of India appointed a Committee under the Chairmanship of Shri D. V. Rege to investigate companyditions of industrial labour. The report referred to the companytract system whereby the factory owner engaged a large number of middlemen supplied them with raw materials and purchased finished products from them.

facts.text: Madras Court of Inquiry (1946) found 90,000 beedi workers, 26,500 women, 2/5 children, poor home worker conditions.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946, the Government of Madras appointed a Court of Inquiry into labour companyditions in beedi, cigar, snuffcuring and tanning industries. There were 90,000 workers depending on beedi industry ill Madras. of these, 26,500 workers were women. Employment of children in the Industry was universal. 2/5th of the total workers were children.

facts.text: Natraj Report (1954) noted only 17,544 of over 1 lakh beedi workers in factories; contract/home systems exploit workers.

anchor.surface_text: In 1954, the Government of India appointed Shri Natraj Inspector of Factories to assess the situation with a view to affording maximum legislative protection to the workers. The Report was as follows. Although the number of workers engaged in the manufacture of beedi exceeded one lakh, only 17,544 were employed in factories.

anchor.surface_text: The High Courts of Madras, Kerala, Gujarat, Mysore and Andhra Pradesh have rightly held the Act to have companystitutional companypetence. ... The Act is valid and falls within Entries 22, 23, and 24 of List III.

facts.text: Sections 3 and 4 of Act (licensing industrial premises) upheld as not violative of Art 14 or 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Sections 3 and 4 of the Act were challenged as violative of Article 19 1  g  and Article 1.4 on account of procedural unreasonableness and companyferment of unfettered powers on the licensing authority without the requisite safeguards. ... anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons the provisions of the Act in particular companytained in sections 2 g   a , 2 g   b  and 2 m  are companystitutionally valid and do number impose any unreasonable restriction on the manufacturer or trade mark holder.

facts.text: Sections 26 and 27 (annual leave with wages) apply to home workers; calculation based on daily average earnings.

anchor.surface_text: The express language of sections 26 and 27 of the Act is relatable to home workers. They work in establishments. The daily average of total full time earnings for the days worked during the month immediately preceding the leave is applicable to home workers.

facts.text: Madras HC held Sections 26,27,31,37(3) unenforceable against trademark holders re home workers (1973 II M.L.J. 126).

The Union of India  1973  11 M.L.J. 126 held the definitions of employer and principal employer in Section 2  g   a  and 2 m  of the Act to be-valid but held that sections 26 and 27 of the Act are wholly unenforceable against the trade mark holders whether with reference to home workers...

facts.text: Bombay HC held Sections 2(g)(a), 2(m) invalid; Sections 26,27 not apply to home workers (1972 1 L.L.J. 130).

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court in M s. Chotabhai Purshottam Patel, Beedi Manufacturers of Bhandara Ors. v. The Bombay High Court further held that the provisions of sections 26 and 27 of the Act will number apply to home workers at all.

facts.text: Mysore HC upheld Sections 3,4,26,27,31 valid (1972 Mysore Law Journal 450).

facts.text: Kerala HC struck down parts of Sections 2(g)(a),2(m),26,27 re home workers (1972 1 L.L.J. 340).

anchor.surface_text: The Kerala High Court in Chirukandeth Chandrasekharan v. Union of India  1972  1 L.L.J. 340 held that the provisions of sections 2  g   a , 2  m  3, 4, 21, 26 and 27 of the Act impose unreasonable restrictions... The Kerala High Court held that sections 26 and 27 will number apply to home workers.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh HC held Sections 3,4 void; Act not apply to home workers.

anchor.surface_text: The Andhra Pradesh High Court in Civil Appeals Nos. 1972 and 1988 of 1971, held that sections 3 and 4 of the Act offend Articles 14 and 19  1   g  of the Constitution and are, therefore, void. The Andhra Pradesh High Court came to the companyclusion that the provisions companytained in sections 3 to 27 of the Act do number apply to home workers.

facts.text: Gujarat HC upheld Act constitutional (CA 585/1971 from judgment 14th/15th October, 1970).

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat High Court, in Civil Appeal No. 585 of 1971, upheld the provisions of the Act to be companystitutional.

facts.text: Alagiriswami J holds Sections 26,27,31,37(3) do not apply to home workers.

facts.text: Principal employer is person for whom/on whose behalf contract labour engaged (Section 2(m)).

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 m  of the Act defines principal employer to mean a person for whom or on whose behalf any companytract labour is engaged or employed in an establishment.

facts.text: Home workers can produce 700-1000 beedis per day; minimum wages Rs.2-4.30 per 1000 pieces.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact it is found that home workers can turn out 700 to 1000 pieces a day. That is the view expressed in the Report of the Royal Commission on labour in India 1931 as also the Labour Investigation Committee Report 1944... The minimum wages prescribed by various states for these home workers are between Rs. 2 to 4.30 for rolling 1000 pieces.

issues.text: Whether Parliament has legislative competence to enact the Beedi and Cigar Workers (Conditions of Employment) Act, 1966, or does it fall exclusively under Entry 24 of List II?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the petitioners contended that entry 24 in list II is the only legislative Entry 24 speaks of industries subject to the, provisions of Entries 7 and 52 of list I. Entry 7 in List I speaks of Industries declared by Parliament by law to be necessary for the purpose of defence or for the projection of war. Entry 52 in List I speaks of Industries the, companytrol of which by the Union is declared by Parliament by law to be expedient in the public interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Licensing guided by objective criteria in s.4 (suitability, experience, resources, bona fides, public interest); reasons required for refusal; appeal provided; no arbitrariness.

holdings.text: Sections 3 and 4 do not impose arbitrary, excessive or extraneous conditions violating Articles 14 and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: violative of Article 19 1  g  and Article 1.4 on account of procedural unreasonableness section 4 of the Act imposes conditions which are arbitrary, excessive extraneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objective considerations in s.4 and procedural safeguards (reasons, appeal) prevent abuse of discretion.

holdings.text: Provisions in sections 2(g)(a), 2(g)(b) and 2(m) are constitutionally valid and do not impose unreasonable restrictions.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons the provisions of the Act in particular contained in sections 2 g   a , 2 g   b  and 2 m  are constitutionally valid and do not impose any unreasonable restriction on the manufacturer or trade mark holder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principal employer liable only for contract labour engaged for/on their behalf, not independent contractors; no vicarious liability; aligns with statutory purpose of welfare.

holdings.text: Sections 26 and 27 apply to home workers; leave wages based on daily average full time earnings for days worked preceding leave.

anchor.surface_text: The express language of sections 26 and 27 of the Act is relatable to home workers. They work in establishments. The daily average of total full time earnings for the days worked during the month immediately preceding the leave is applicable to home workers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express textual application to employees in establishments (includes home workers per s.2(f),(h)); calculable via records of days worked/piece rates; no minimum days like Factories Act; reasonable incentive to work.

holdings.text: Employer-employee relationship determined by multi-factor test including control, organisation, equipment, right to reject, not exclusive control test.

anchor.surface_text: control test as traditionally formulated has not been treated as an exclusive test

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedents (Silver Jubilee Tailoring, etc.); relevant factors indicate relation justifying liability under Act.

holdings.text: Sections 26, 27, 31 and 37(3) do not apply to home workers (Alagiriswami J concurring opinion).

anchor.surface_text: It has to be held in agreement with the majority of the High Courts that sections 26. 27, 31 and 37 3  do number apply to the home workers. It would be good in the interest of all concerned if the Act is amended as early as possible to remove all the lacunas and the difficulties pointed out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Practical difficulties in implementation for home workers (variable hours, wage calc, maternity); agrees with high courts; suggests amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Courts of Madras, Kerala, Gujarat, Mysore and Andhra Pradesh have rightly held the Act to have constitutional competence. ... The Act is valid and falls within Entries 22, 23, and 24 of List III.

The Act is valid and falls within Entries 22, 23, and 24 of List III.
